para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-6-622 provides that the state of a witness' feelings toward the parties and his relationship to them may always be considered by the jury. A witness may be biased for or against a party, but a generalized bias is not sufficient to rise to the level of self-interested motive.[1] This provision of the Code was carried forward from the old Code without substantive change.

In City of Atlanta v. Grier,[2] an officer's personal interest in the case was a factor for jury consideration, but did not mean that his testimony was not substantive evidence. However, in Conley v. Gallup,[3] the “financial interest” of defendant's expert witnesses who were initial contributors and insured by the Medical Association of Georgia, defendant's medical malpractice insurer, was not such as to render this evidence admissible as more material than prejudicial.

Likewise, in Chrysler Group, LLC v. Walden,[4] the Court of Appeals allowed testimony regarding Chrysler's CEO's salary because evidence of his compensation could be used by the jury to consider whether he had an interest in providing testimony favorable to his employer that insulated it from liability. While the Georgia Supreme Court affirmed this ruling,[5] the Supreme Court further reasoned that a witness's compensation, like other wealth evidence, must be analyzed in each case under Rule 401 (whether it is probative), and then under Rule 403 (whether it is more prejudicial than probative). Thus, a witness's compensation may be relevant and admissible to show bias, but the trial court must analyze this under those two rules.

Bias sufficient to show witness partiality must arise from a motive of self-interest or self-preservation that could reasonably be inferred may distort the witnesses' testimony.[6] In Carlisle v. Abend,[7] the court denied the plaintiff's bias evidence that a defendant surgeon's expert witness testified on behalf of the defendant in a prior medical malpractice case because it would have revealed that the surgeon had been sued before and suggested that he had a proclivity for negligent conduct. In Virger v. State,[8] the Court allowed testimony that the defendant abused the witness for the purpose of demonstrating that the witness's favorable statements towards the defendant may have been motivated by fear of the defendant's retaliation.

As with impeachment by prior inconsistent statement, an examining attorney must lay a proper foundation on cross-examination before introducing evidence of a witness's bias against a party. The inquiry is terminated if a witness admits his ill feelings toward a party on cross-examination.[9] However, if he denies ill feelings, then counsel may introduce evidence of particular transactions.[10] If the witness still denies ill feelings, then counsel may introduce evidence similar to reputation testimony to show ill feelings.[11]

In Childers v. Floyd,[12] the Eleventh Circuit vacated a prior panel's reading of the Confrontation Clause and used three U.S. Supreme Court cases[13] to interpret broadly a court's discretion to limit cross-examination.[14] In affirming the trial court's decision, the Eleventh Circuit held that courts may not prohibit all questioning into witnesses' biases, but they do have broad discretion to limit further cross-examination after defendant has exposed some evidence of bias. Likewise, the courts in Georgia have held that a defendant has a right to a thorough and sifting cross-examination where a witness believes he or she would receive a personal benefit from testifying favorably for the state. The court retains wide latitude in imposing reasonable limits on such a cross-examination.[15]
Of course, if a juror is biased against a party or witness, this may be examined to determine if the defendant's Sixth Amendment right to a fair trial has been compromised.[16]

In Noellien v. State, 298 Ga. App. 47, 679 S.E.2d 75 (2009), defendant's generalized “grudge” against police did not rise to the level of a self-interested motive specific to the case. In Anthony v. State, 303 Ga. 399, 811 S.E.2d 399 (2018), the Court upheld the limitation on cross-examination of a witness regarding bias in favor of the state where the defendant was unable to provide any evidence regarding the dismissal of a prostitution charge against the witness.
